author: chris2_2_2
content: Oh I mean the dev meeting notes: https://github.com/ethereum/pm/blob/master/AllCoreDevs-Meetings/Meeting%20134.md

author: chris2_2_2
content:
An obvious example of a critical correction:

"You know, early June around mid June June and July, we would probably have like 14-15 second block times, which is high, but not manageable and late July early August, assuming like things are the same, you probably are lucky he had like 17 or more and that's supposed to be. "

I assume Tim meant to say manageable.

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!552133098075193354> would be the right person to ask if PRs to meeting notes would be valuable.

author: sky.cactus
content: My *guess* is it probably isn't worth fixing them up.

author: timbeiko
content: FWIW, I (likely) said 14-15 sec is not *un*manageable

author: chris2_2_2
content: Yeah I figured. One issue with the notes is that the meaning of things changes in a few places because of errors. Was wondering if the critical  errors should be corrected I can submit a pr for the ones I saw but likely due to lack of technical knowledge I will miss some.

author: timbeiko
content: I think if we wanted to deeply proofread them, weâ€™d basically need to double the cost. Perhaps thatâ€™s worth considering, cc: <@!642887713246150666>

author: poojaranjan
content: This looks like a typo, because rest of the details on the Readme seems to be correct. I suppose, PR #503 was to update the Readme file till meeting ACD 134. Thanks for user (misher2 ) for making a new PR to fix the typo.

author: poojaranjan
content: PRs for ACD and CL meetings are usually available within 5 days of the meeting. Any correction in the period before it is merged, is highly appreciated. However, anyone can make a PR to update that later. In this case, I can follow up with the user (who documented the notes) to update it, if that's helpful.

author: poojaranjan
content:
In my experience, documenting ACD and CL meetings are generally  a little challenging for non-tech user (who document the notes) and they try their best to document with the help of captions and own ability to pick up the correct term.

I would not rely 100 % on the notes, however happy to invite people who are willing to proof read and will also look into the cost part of documentation, if that's helpful. 

I think, one immediate measure that can be helpful could be adding time stamp in notes at places of confusion or important piece of information. So, people be able to follow the recording at the point in case of clarification.

author: poojaranjan
content: I will get this fixed ASAP.
